(Photo: [[Morten Krogvold]], 2010) | birth_date = | birth_place = Kristiansand, Norway | nationality = Norwegian | known_for = Radio and television executive | occupation = Radio and television executive }} '''Tor Fuglevik''' (born 7 April 1950) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] radio and television executive.[https://snl.no/Tor_Aslak_Fuglevik ''Store norske leksikon'': «Tor Aslak Fuglevik»] While Director General for Radio at the [[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]], Fuglevik founded the very first all-[[digital radio]] channel ([[Digital Audio Broadcasting|DAB]]) in the world. The [[NRK Klassisk]] channel, broadcasting classical music 24 hours a day, was launched on 1 June 1995.[http://www.ballade.no/nmi.nsf/doc/art2005053014180589782558 www.ballade.no] Tor Fuglevik holds degrees from the Norwegian [[School of Journalism]] in Oslo and the [[University of Oslo]]. He started his career as a radio news reporter for the [[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] (NRK) in 1971. He was appointed Head of Information at the [[Norwegian Ministry of Justice and the Police]] in 1976. Fuglevik has since held various positions at NRK, acting as Regional Manager, Radio Director General and Dep. Director General. From 2002 to 2006 he was Director General of [[Norges Televisjon]] (NTV), a company set up to establish a national, terrestrial TV network, and since 2006 has served as Director of the Norwegian branch of the international media conglomerate [[Modern Times Group]]. From 2004 to 2010, he was a board member of the Language Council of Norway, which is the consultative body for the Norwegian state and government on language issues. During his career, Fuglevik has also been a member of various governing bodies within the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) in [[Geneva]]. Fuglevik has published several books about radio and broadcasting. In 2008, Tor Fuglevik received The Honorary Award of Prix Radio for his contribution to the development of Norwegian Radio.[http://www.lokalradio.no/?artikkel=1053 Norsk LokalradioForbund] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.aftenposten.no/reise/article2881387.ece Interview with Tor Fuglevik in Norwegian newspaper Afteposten, January 24th 2009] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fuglevik, Tor}} [[Category:University of Oslo alumni]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

Baron de Gennin Hyatt Regency Ekaterinburg, Iset, Demidov Plaza, President]] '''Yekaterinburg-City''' ({{lang-rus|Екатеринбург-Сити}}, ''Yekaterinburg-Siti'')<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.apiural.ru/news/economy/26724/|title=Администрация города определила этапы реализации мегапроекта "Екатеринбург-Сити" - Новости - АПИ-Урал|website=www.apiural.ru|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref> is a [[commercial district]] in central [[Yekaterinburg]], [[Russia]]. It is located on Boris Yeltsin Street on the embankment of the [[Iset River]] and is currently under development. The area occupies five [[hectares]].
The project's architectural planning and design belonged to French architectural bureau [[ValoDia and Pistre]]. The project's primary investor is [[UMMK-Holding]]. Construction would be responsible to Deputy Mayor for Construction and Architecture, Vladimir Kritskii. The project combines about 450,000 square meters of commercial space, offices, hotels, entertainment centers, cafes, and restaurants. The plans include 12 buildings: four office towers, a commercial area to accommodate typical small and average-sized businesses, a so-called trading gallery and two hotels.<ref name=":0" />
Construction of Yekaterinburg-City started in 2007 and is scheduled to complete in 2014.<ref name=":0" /> Progress had a setback in 2014 due to the [[Russian financial crisis (2014–present)|Russian financial crisis]] but government officials stated that it would still be finished by 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lands-sale.com/real_estate/Ekaterinburg-City_completed_in_2014_despite_the_crisis_12576|title=Ekaterinburg-City completed in 2014, despite the crisis - Mayor|last=I.I.|first=Ivanov|website=www.lands-sale.com|language=en|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref> However, two skyscrapers of Yekaterinburg-City were finished over the expected completion date of 2014 in 2015.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
Yekaterinburg-City currently has three skyscrapers, one hotel, and two high-rises.
